 1. INTRODUCTION 1.1 Hungary has experienced a major public finance crisis starting in 1994. An excessively gradualist approach to the public sector reform, based on the desire to ensure social stability during the transition, has led to unsustainable levels of expenditures and fiscal deficits. The large budget deficits have expanded Hungary's public debt. With gross external debt of 70 percent of GDP, and a debt service of 8 percent of GDP, Hungary is one of the most heavily indebted countries. 1.2 Faced with large internal and external macro imbalances, the Hungarian authorities announced in March 1995 a package of stabilization measures, including: (a) significant cuts in fiscal expenditures; (b) strict wage controls in the public sector; (c) increases in fiscal revenues; and, (d) an up-front devaluation of 9 percent and introduction of a pre-announced crawling peg. The stabilization efforts continued in 1996 and included a strict budgetary policy. This policy has led to significant improvements. The consolidated government deficit (excluding privatization revenues) is expected to be reduced to 4 percent of GDP in 1996 from a record level of 8.4 percent in 1994. The estimated revenues and expenditures of the general government in 1996, at 46 percent, and 50 percent respectively, are 7 and 11 percent, respectively, lower than in 1994. The primary balance of the general government (excluding interest revenues and expenditures) shows an even more radical improvement, from a deficit of 2.7 percent in 1994 to an expected surplus of 3.7 percent in 1997. These measures and further fiscal corrections are needed to maintain the budget and current account deficits at sustainable levels. Moreover, major structural reforms in the public sector and in the banking and enterprise sectors are necessary to reduce the size of the State, release resources for the private sector, and thus to ensure a high and sustainable growth. 1.3 To address the most severe structural weaknesses in the public sector, the Government has prepared a plan for a comprehensive public finance reform. The reform of the public sector is expected to be fully implemented over a period of about four years, starting in 1996. The public finance reform program emphasizes institutional improvements that yield the largest budgetary savings, promote transparency of actions, while simultaneously increase the efficiency of public services and of the allocation of public resources. The program concentrates on restructuring and reforming: (a) the welfare system; (b) tax policy and tax administration; (c) public administration and public finance management; and (d) intergovernmental finances. 1.4 The reform of public finance management is necessary to improve the allocation of public resources. The organization and financial management of government operations face several major problems. First, widespread earmarking of revenues reduces the flexibility in reallocating scarce public resources to priority needs. Second, anticipated budget management practices hamper effective expenditure control. Third, public debt management is inefficient and suffers from too fragmented responsibilities with independent borrowing authority granted to various
 2 agencies. Fourth, the government financial information system is inadequate for budget planning and execution.a 1.5 The Government has launched a three-year plan, starting in 1996, to improve financial planning, budget execution and a better coordination in financing government deficits. This plan involves major changes in institutional arrangements, including the budgeting process. Budgetary institutions at the central level are being rationalized; number of extrabudgetary funds reduced; skills required in public administration redefined; and the employment management and structure in the public sector reformed. In January 1996, the Government undertook a critical step to ensure budgetary control by establishing a Treasury, and introducing an interim Government Financial Management Information System (GFMIS). According to the 1996 Budget Law approved by Parliament in December 1995 and the amendment to the Law on Public Finances approved in November 1995, all central budgetary institutions and most extrabudgetary funds have been absorbed into the Treasury system. A Council of Treasury consisting of representatives from the MOF, the NBH and the Treasury has been established as a decision-making body to coordinate the monetary, fiscal and debt policies. 1.6 The IMF has been advising the Government on setting up the Treasury and on key aspects of budget preparation and expenditure management over the last two years. The US Treasury and the UK Know How Fund are also rendering advice to the Government on budget and treasury matters. The Bank has been collaborating with both the IMF and the bilateral providers of technical assistance to assist the Government in its reforms and in preparing a Public Sector Adjustment Loan (PSAL). 1.7 The Government has approached the Bank to finance the development and implementation of new systems, processes, procedures and methodologies required for the implementation of the new institutional structure and processes of public finance, associated with the revised budgetary processes and treasury operations and management. The Bank has evaluated the proposals and has found the proposed project justified for financing because it: - addresses priority problems (chapter 2); - fits within an overall program for public sector reform (chapter 3); - takes into account lessons from prior Bank experience and is in accord with the Country Assistance Strategy (CAS) (chapter 4); - has priority objectives and needed content (chapter 5); - has reasonable costs and a feasible implementation plan (chapter 6 &7); - would confer important benefits in public finance management (chapter 8); the risks are limited and worth taking (chapter 8). THE PREVIOUS SYSTEM AND ITS SHORT COMINGS 2.1 Previous analyses by the Hungarian Authorities and by the LIMF and the World Bank staff highlighted significant weaknesses in the budget system and the financial management of government operations. These have been reported on in previous Bank and IMF reports (e.g. Hungary--Strengthening the Financial Management of Government Operations--IMFJFAD, July 1994, PSAL Concept Paper -January 1996- World Bank). The features of the previous system that hindered effective financial management in the central and local governments are summarized below. Structure of Government 2.2 The structure of the Hungarian Government and the nature of the general government financial flows could be characterized as extremely decentralized, which significantly hindered effective budget preparation and execution, as well as cash and debt management. Lack of control over Central Budgetary Institution (CBI) activities also retarded potential efficiency improvements in resource allocation. CBIs, in addition to performning state tasks as specified in their enabling legislation, could supplement their resources by engaging in additional tasks, some of which are clearly commercial in nature. However, given the implicit subsidies on the inputs they used (equipment, labor, utilities), the prices charged for the goods and services sold by CBIs did not reflect the cost to society of the resources used. In addition, widespread earmarking of revenues reduced the flexibility in reallocating scarce public resources to priority needs. Budget Preparation 2.3 Under the previous information system (para 2.7), the final data on budgetary chapter revenues and expenditures, including activities of the CBIs and Extra-Budgetary Funds (EBFs) that they supervise, were often not available. One result of this was a persistent underestimation of budgetary chapter revenues, generally the own revenues of CBIs. The unavailability of timely and sufficiently disaggregated data on CBI revenues and expenditure made it difficult to reallocate budgetary resources among CBIs both within budgetary chapters and among chapters. Moreover, limitations in the data reporting system hindered chapters and the MOF in examining the efficiency with which these programs are administered. Finally, although data on end-year cash balances for each budgetary institution (chapters, CBIs, FBFs) were available, the lack of detailed data on revenues and expenditures did not allow the MOF to adjust annual budgetary transfers in light of previous year's own revenue performance. Given the CBIs' ability to collect, retain and spend own revenues, a right explicitly given in the Law on Public Finance, the total revenue and expenditure levels proposed by the Government and approved by Parliament were in fact not rigid limits, but were instead indicative targets.
 4 Budget Execution 2.4 The decentralized nature of central government operations, and the absence of a central Treasury, posed difficulties in effective and efficient cash and debt management. Budgetary institutions in Hungary had individual bank accounts. Because the CBIs have independent responsibility for own revenues and total expenditures, and because of limitations on the timeliness of information generated by the previous system, the MOF and the NBH had difficulties in forecasting net government credit. 2.5 The State Insurance Funds (SIFs) were separated from the state budget in 1989 and split into separate pension and health care funds in 1993. However, for some important aspects of debt and cash management, they were for all intents and purposes still part of the state budget. They had access to the state budget's Liquidity Fund to cover revenue shortfalls. Their revenue and expenditure accounts were separate from the Liquidity Fund accounts, however, and the MOF was not aware of their projected cash flows. This of course hindered efficient cash and debt management, and posed difficulties in formulating and executing effectively monetary policy. 2.6 The SIFs, as well as particular EBFs, are granted, in the context of the annual budget, authority to borrow independently of the state budget. Allowing decentralized borrowing powers makes macroeconomic control difficult as it is more difficult to convince the independent borrowers of the need for adjustments in their activities consistent with changing economic circumstances. Fiscal Information System 2.7 As mentioned above, the fiscal information system was inadequate in providing timely and sufficiently detailed data on government operations in a form that is useful for policy making, execution and control. It should be noted that, following the adoption of the Law on Public Finance (LPF), detailed semi-annual reports were required from all budgetary institutions at the central government level, as well as aggregated data at the local level. In addition, less detailed "flash" reports were required at the end of each quarter. In spite of these improvements, budget preparation, execution and control continued to be hobbled by the system. Without adequate time to analyze detailed data by institution and by program, the Government was not able to use public money efficiently. The budget continued to be prepared with less than appropriate knowledge of the present circumstances. 2.8 The lack of timely information also did not allow adequate expenditure verification and control. Moreover, without an effective on-line system, it was not possible to effect rapidly cutbacks in budgeted expenditures that became necessary in the face of changing macroeconomic circumstances or revenue shortfalls. Finally, the lack of information did not allow appropriate consolidation of government revenues and expenditures. Debt Management 2.9 Weaknesses were also present in the management of the public debt. Specifically these included: (a) fragmented institutional responsibilities for debt management; (b) independent
 5 borrowing authority granted to certain government agencies; (c) government financing by the National Bank of Hungary (NBH); (d) excessive diversification of government debt instruments and of issuing techniques which hindered the deepening of the secondary market; and (e) insufficient emphasis on creating institutional conditions (in particular a strengthened legal and regulatory framework and adequate supervision) for the smooth functioning and development of this market. 2.10 Shortcomings of the system highlighted in the foregoing paragraphs led to the development of the Government's reform program for fiscal management described below. 3. REFORM STRATEGY AND PROGRAMS A. IMF Recommendations 3.1 The main reform measures recommended by a series of IMF (Fiscal Affairs Department) missions are summarized below. 3.2 The Budget Process The central government budget should include the detailed budgets of: the state, including the budgetary chapters; each of the CBIs and extra-budgetary funds. The approved expenditures for each budgetary chapter and each of the other central government agencies should represent mandatory limits for the budget year. Modifications to the approved budgets should, in principle, be authorized by Parliament through supplementary budgets. 3.3 The current classification scheme for the budget should be revised, with a view to improving its usefulness for economic analysis and to allow accurate consolidation of intragovernmental flows of revenues and expenditures. 3.4 Government agencies should be required to maintain records of (and once a computerized financial information system has been set up, register in it) all phases of expenditures, namely the commitment of funds, verification of the obligation to pay, issuance of the payment order, and actual disbursement of funds. 3.5 Financial Management of Government Operations. As a matter of priority, and in line with the practice of most western economies, a State Treasury should be established within the Ministry of Finance. The Treasury should have as primary responsibilities: (a) planning and ensuring the orderly financial execution of the budgets of the central government, including the CBIs and the extra-budgetary and social insurance funds; and of the transfers between central and local governments; and (b) planning and coordinating the financing of government deficits. 3.6 The Liquidity Fund of the state and the bank accounts of budgetary chapters, CBIs, extra- budgetary funds and social insurance funds should be consolidated into a Treasury Single Account (TSA) at the NBH. This step needs to be accompanied by the development and progressive implementation of a computerized, on-line government financial management information system (GFMIS), the main features of which are outlined below. The consolidation of the bank accounts of the above-mentioned entities into a single Treasury Account would be accompanied by the creation of ledger accounts for these agencies in the GFMIS. All revenues
 6 would be deposited in the T'SA, but would also be credited simultaneously to the appropriate account in the GFMIS. Transfers between agencies would be registered in the GFMIS, but would not affect the TSA. Only payments to entities outside the system would be debited to the TSA. This, of course, would help reduce the financing requirements of the Treasury, and consequently the interest charges to the budget. 3.7 The financial consolidation of government balances would be compatible with the continuation of a decentralized execution of the budgets of government agencies. The Treasury would continue to ensure an orderly flow of transfers from the state budget to the other agencies. The agencies would be able to effect (within the limit of the relevant budgetary allocation) any payment for which they had sufficient balance in their GFMIS account. 3.8 An overview of the proposed GFMIS structure and functions is given at Annex I. B. The Government's Reform Program 3.9 The Government has now prepared, in association with Bank staff and following the IMF recommendations, a plan to address the most severe structural weaknesses in the public sector. Some initial measures have been implemented as part of the 1995 stabilization package and further measures were planned for 1996. The public sector reform program involves expenditure reforms, including a major reform of the local government and pension system; reductions in cash benefits combined with better targeting of transfers to the poorest households; and a plan to reduce employment in the civil service; revenue system reforms, including gradual reductions in payroll taxes; a realignment of the personal income tax structure; and improvements in tax administration; and reforms in budgetary institutions and the budgeting processes, including the establishment of a Treasury. 3.10 The proposed reform program will introduce changes in the institutional structure of public finance and in the budgeting process. The program will focus as a priority on institutional improvements that yield the largest budgetary savings, promote transparency of actions and simultaneously reduce waste of state resources and increase the efficiency of public services. Complementing these measures, the Government is launching a three year program to establish a Treasury, to improve financial planning, budget execution and better coordination of the financing of government deficits generated by the various subsystems of public finance. 3.11 Establishment of a Treasury. rhe Government has established a central Treasury to improve: (a) financial planning; (b) financial execution of the budgets of budgetary chapters, autonomous central budgetary institutions, extra-budgetary funds and Social Security funds and of transfers between central and local governments; and (c) planning and coordination of the financing of government deficits. The separate accounts of central budgetary institutions and, particularly, the liquidity fund -- the central MOF account, which is the net balance of many credit and debit accounts maintained by NBH -- have been progressively consolidated into a Treasury Single Account (TSA) maintained by NBH. This consolidation took place with effect from January 1, 1996. This will be complemented by the development of a GFMIS, incorporating ledger accounts for both budget preparation and implementation and a system to monitor financial flows. As a result, all government revenues would be deposited in the TSA and simultaneously credited to the GFMIS. Transfers between agencies would be registered in the GFMIS but would not affect
 7 the TSA position. Only payments outside of the TSA system would be debited. In this way, the Treasury system is expected to lead to a more efficient cash management and savings in financing of the Government. 3.12 The Treasury has been structured into central and regional directorates. The central directorate would concentrate on policy, regulation and control over the Treasury operations, the execution of national cash and debt management, and would provide the executive and parliamentary bodies with financial management information for decision making. The regional directorates would perform the day-to-day Treasury and accounting services to the government agencies in their geographical areas, interface with the local branches of the National Bank of Hungary for access to the TSA, and with the central directorate for information exchange. 3.13 Under a decree of July 1995 and an Amendment of the Act on Public Finance of November 1995, the Treasury is expected to: (a) enforce a strict relationship between the budget appropriation and payments; (b) implement new systems for cash and debt management; (c) eliminate the transfer of cash in transactions between government agencies; (d) implement a homogenous accounting system and GFMIS to increase the transparency of budget execution and the quality of financial information available to government agencies; (e) implement a centralized TSA at the NBH; (f) ensure that all government receipts and payments to non-governmental agencies are transacted through the TSA; and (g) carry out detailed accounting for agencies connected to the system. 3.14 The Government has set up a task force in the MOF, headed by a Deputy Secretary of State having the rank of Ministerial Commissioner, to fully implement the establishment of the central Treasury system. Implementation of the Treasury systems and of the GFMIS is expected to take place during 1996-98 with the following major actions: * January 1, 1996 - Adjust legal framework for government financial management; adopt required budget and accounting nomenclatures; start operation of the Treasury Single Account; absorb all central budgetary institutions and extra budgetary funds into the Treasury circle; eliminate cash payments between government agencies, including collection of social security tax for public employees; start effecting payments against payment orders generated by the CBIs in response to specific vendor invoices, rather than by pre-financing agencies in anticipation of such payments. Government institutions would maintain detailed accounting records but would assure that accounting is based on the new classification system and Treasury management regulations. * January 1, 1997 - Extend the above mentioned measures to other central budgetary organizations and public bodies, including the social security institutions; start providing detailed GFMIS based accounting and management reporting to the central government and its agencies. Government institutions would still retain parallel accounting as a security measure.
 8 3.15 According to the original decree, Treasury operations were to be extended to local government (municipalities) and public bodies outside the central budget. However, due to the legislative complexity involved in the incorporation of local governments into the treasury circle, and the specialized nature of the local government financial systems, Government has subsequently decided that this issue required more examination. The above-mentioned decree was accordingly modified in April 1996, postponing the incorporation of the local governments into the Treasury. C. Progress To Date 3.16 Reforms have progressed substantially since the government decision of July 4, 1995, with a number of initiatives proceeding in parallel. These are summarized below. 3.17 Treasury Operations. The January 1996 actions have been accomplished. The legal and policy steps have been implemented according to the timetable. The necessary high level amendments to the legal framework have been developed. The changes were approved by Parliament in November, 1995. The detailed regulations and procedures necessary for the day- to-day operation of a treasury system have been developed. 3.18 An interim Treasury Ledger System (TLS) has been developed by the Treasury to accommodate appropriation accounting for the CBI's and EBF's (absorbed into the Budget) at an aggregate level. This system has been implemented from January 1, 1996. Some of the main conceptual elements of the treasury system, namely a single account for government operations, a centralized ledger system, and a payment system based on payment orders rather than advance funding are in place. However, the interim system does not include a number of important functions required in a full GFMIS and further conceptual design work is necessary. 3.19 Budgeting. Work has commenced, with the assistance of the US Treasury, to classify the Budget consistent with GFS methodology, and develop a chart of accounts for use in the final Treasury System. The central budget preparation process is already well formalized and logical in approach. 3.20 The budget preparation process is supported by a computer-based system capable of rapidly collating the figures from ministries (supplied by email, on diskette or on paper) and performing re-calculations where necessary. The system is also connected directly to the Parliament building to allow changes required by Parliament to be incorporated immediately into the database. The Budget Department is in the process of upgrading considerably the IT capability (the database software will be significantly enhanced with a move from MICROSOFT ACCESS to ORACLE). 3.21 However, the fiscal information system must be upgraded, so that the final data on budgetary chapter revenues and expenditures, including central budgetary institutions and extra- budgetary fimds, are made available for the preparation of the annual budget and for effective budget execution and control. The Budget Department needs to improve its access to necessary information from local governments and from the Social Security Funds. Ultimately, not only the Treasury, but also local governments will need to update their information technologies to be able to support a proper budget preparation process.
 9 3.22 Following recommendations developed under PSAL, the government program also acknowledges the need to improve coordination between the budget preparation and budget execution areas. This will involve bringing together the development of a budget preparation system with the work on the Treasury system. The databases of both budget preparation and budget implementation will be constructed on one identical chart of accounts and at the same level of detail. Thus, under the Public Financial Management Reform program, the existing databases will be consolidated, and compatible operating software systems will be developed and harmonized across the Budgeting Department and the Treasury. 3.23 The IMF has been advising the Government on setting up the Treasury and on key aspects of budget preparation and expenditure management over the last two years. The US Treasury and the UK Know How Fund are also rendering advice to the Govermment on budget and treasury matters. The Bank has been collaborating with both the IMF and the bilateral providers of technical assistance to assist the Government in its reforms and in preparing a Public Sector Adjustment Loan. 3.24 Debt Management. The Debt Management Office of the Treasury manages the issue and recording of domestic debt. The NBH is currently responsible for external debt management. The current set of systems used for management of the issue and recording of domestic debt instruments is fragmented. It includes five different groups of information systems to assist in the processes of public trading, auction of treasury bills, over-the-counter trading of government issues, and to assist in record keeping and analysis of domestic debt data. The Treasury has recently completed an analysis of the deficiencies of the current set of information systems to assist in the management of domestic debt and has developed a statement of overall functional requirements. The Treasury is examining proposals for the design and implementation of an integrated system for the management of domestic debt. 4. LESSONS OF EXPERIENCE AND BANK STRATEGY Lessons Learned 4.1 Sector experience of the Bank and the Tax Administration Modernization Project (3635- HU) in Hungary indicates that projects with a sizable amount of technical assistance and information systems investment should: (a) be carefully focused, particularly to provide adequate attention to functional design issues prior to computerization issues to ensure effective and efficient implementation; (b) have the active support of government and ministry officials, to ensure properly considered and timely decision-making on crucial issues; and (c) have a well-defined procurement plan including terms of reference for consultants and studies, drafted and agreed with the Borrower prior to negotiations. 4.2 Based on these lessons the Public Finance Management Project will focus on four specific areas for which govermnent commitment and financing have been secured. A procurement plan, including terms of reference for consultants and studies were drafted and agreed with the Borrower prior to negotiations, and finalized during negotiations. Also, given the importance of institutional
 10 capacity building and information systems in the project, the project team will closely supervise handling of the design, procurement and implementation challenges. Rationale for Bank Involvement 4.3 The project is consistent with the Country Assistance Strategy (CAS) for Hungary which was discussed by the Executive Directors on June 15, 1995. The objectives of the CAS are to help Hungary maintain macroeconomic stability and accelerate its growth to facilitate EU accession; reform public finance and social policy and strengthen the human resource base; and strengthen and privatize Hungary's financial and enterprise sectors. The PFMP will focus on reforming the institutional structure of public finance and on the budgeting process. By designing and implementing the necessary tools, the project will assist the Government in both implementing and monitoring the required measures of the public finance reform. The project will also complement the Public Sector Adjustment Loan, which is currently under preparation and aims at restructuring Hungary's social expenditures, particularly pension and health care. 5. THE PROJECT Objectives 5.1 The overall objective of the project is to assist the Government to optimize the deployment and use of its financial resources through changes in the institutional structure of public finance and in the budgeting process by: (a) introducing improved methods, guidelines and systems for budget preparation, macroeconomic forecasting and, particularly, preparation of forward estimates; (b) ensuring smooth and timely execution of the budget, while minimizing the cost of government financing through the newly established Treasury; (c) optimizing the management of public debt; and, (d) designing and setting up coordinating mechanisms, policies, procedures and standards that would ensure that the different elements of the Government's Public Finance Management (PFM) network can function as an integrated whole. 5.2 This project would assist the Government in designing and implementing a set of tools to enable it to move forward in the implementation of planned changes in the institutional structure ofpublicfinance and in the budgeting process. Project Description 5.3 The project focuses on the key initiatives of the Government's program of Public Financial Management Reform. The proposed project is organized into four components and will provide technical assistance, computer equipment and software to assist the authorities to
 I1 design, develop and implement processes, procedures, systems, related regulations and training programs for: (a) Budget Preparation; (b) Treasury Operations; (c) Debt Management; and, (d) Policies, procedures and standards for the PFM information systems network. (a) Budget Preparation (base cost US$0.978 million) 5.4 For this component, technical assistance would be provided to: (i) develop improved methods and guidelines for budget preparation, macroeconomic forecasting and preparation of forward estimates; (ii) review the existing budget coding structures, and, if necessary develop and design a revised structure and chart of accounts conforming with the GFS and the EU classification methodologies and suitable for both budget preparation and implementation; and (iii) develop a functional design of systems, processes and procedures for budget preparation. The project would then provide technical assistance, computer hardware and software during implementation to: (a) implement the revised budget coding structure and chart of accounts for the central government; (b) develop detailed regulations and operating manuals; (c) develop the technical design and implement an information system to assist the Government in the budget preparation process. This would include incorporating modifications to the existing information system for budget preparation so as to ensure that it is able to record the budget appropriations in the same form including the use of an identical chart of accounts and level of detailed breakdown that is used during the budget implementation phase by the treasury system; and (d) design and develop a training strategy and plan for the implementation of the revised budget preparation system. (b) Treasury Operations (base cost US$3.97 million) 5.5 Technical assistance is being provided under a PHRD grant to build on prior work done by the Govermnent towards the development and implementation of the interim treasury system which is now operational. Technical assistance will also be provided to develop the full functional design of systems, processes and procedures for expenditure control and treasury operations to complete the design of a full function Treasury Ledger System (TLS). Particular attention would be paid to incorporating all elements of the expenditure control process, including checking for budget appropriations, prior commitment and verification for receipt of goods and services, prior to authorizing payment. The necessary detailed regulations and operating manuals would also be developed. It is critical that work under the Treasury Operations component be closely coordinated with that of the Budget Preparation component and that the databases for both systems use an identical chart of accounts to provide for the proper
 12 functioning of the budget execution processes. This will be ensured during the design of the Treasury system. During implementation, the project would provide technical assistance, computer hardware and software to enable the Government to complete the technical design of the system and implement the system at the Central Treasury and the Regional Treasury Units. (c) Debt Management (base cost US$1.63 million) 5.6 In this area, technical assistance would be provided to enable the Government to develop improved methods, regulations and guidelines for debt recording, reporting and issuance. The work would be carried out in close cooperation with the agencies responsible for both domestic and foreign debt management to: (a) develop improved methods and functional design of systems for ledgers of domestic, foreign and the aggregate public debt, and government sureties and advances; (b) design an appropriate standardization of debt instruments, auction rules and calendar of issuance and refunding, for both the foreign and domestic debt; and, (c) develop an action plan that would assist the government debt management offices coordinate and optimize their debt policies vis-a-vis the government securities market, including further institutional development of the central registries of dealers and investors, and surveillance of dealers and audit. Control Process in Public Expenditure Management 31. The commitment to expend public money should be governed by an explicit set of rules and procedures to ensure that expenditures correspond to the amounts and purposes decided in the budget--and of course to prevent fraud and abuse. In the commitment/payment/reporting process three clear stages can be identified: a. Before the commitment is made (financial control--commitment stage): At this stage, it is necessary to confirm: that the proposal to spend money has been approved by an authorized person; that the budget has appropriated money for the purpose and sufficient money remains available in the proper appropriation category; that the expenditure is proposed under the correct category. b. Before payment is made (accounting control--verification stage): Before money is withdrawn from the TSA it is necessary to confirm that: a valid obligation exists (established after the commitment stage); an authorized person has certified that the service has been performed as expected; the invoice or other document requesting payment is correct and suitable for payment; and the creditor is correctly identified. 32. After final payment is made (audit): In the context of certifying the financial reports relating to the financial year in question, the Court of Audit would: * examine and scrutinize any or all expenditures or transactions to the extent it chooses; and * report any irregularities, in a manner and to whom it considers appropriate. 33. doc.abstracts: The overall objective of the Public Finance Management Project (PFMP) is to assist the Government to optimize the deployment and use of its financial resources through changes in the institutional structure of public finance and in the budgeting process. The PFMP will focus on the key initiatives of the Government's program of public financial management reform and will be organized into four components. The budget preparation component will assist in development and implementation of improvements for budget preparation, macroeconomic forecasting and preparation of forward estimation, and training staff for the revised budget system implementation. The treasury operations component will introduce the Treasury Ledger System, develop effective cash management methodologies, and establish revised budget execution processes and a new treasury system. Work under the debt management component will involve the development of improvements for the recording, reporting and issuance of government debt, and a training strategy for the implementation of the revised debt management system. The public finance management information systems network will put in place policies, procedures and standards that will ensure coordination among efforts.
